Main_Event_Annotation: The system reached tropical cyclone status and was named Amelia, which categorizes it under the Tropical Storm/Cyclone main event.
Hazards_Annotation: According to the Main_Event–Hazard association table for Tropical Storm/Cyclone events, the implied hazards are wind, flood, and lightning.

Time_Annotation: “On 10 January, a weak tropical low formed in the Gulf of Carpentaria from a monsoon trough.” “Despite moving over land, the system continued to organise and reached cyclone intensity at 18:00 UTC on 15 January, while the centre was located near Wadeye.” “The system made its final landfall south of Perth on January 22 and dissipated soon after.”
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: “Bruno caused torrential rainfall to many areas of Western Australia, especially in the southwest...” This sentence indicates that regions within Australia were affected.
Main_Event_Annotation: “The storm, now named Bruno, continued to develop over the Joseph Bonaparte Gulf and reached an initial peak intensity...” This indicates that the event is a tropical cyclone.
Hazards_Annotation: “Bruno reached an initial peak intensity with winds of 90 km/h (55 mph) and produced gale-force winds...” and “Bruno caused torrential rainfall... Severe flooding occurred in the southwest...” indicate the hazards of wind and flood.

Time_Annotation: The system was first identified on 11 January, became a tropical cyclone at 09:00 UTC the next day, reached its peak intensity early on 16 January, and on the 19th accelerated towards the southeast and weakened, dissipating a few days later.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Daphne-Fifi slowly intensified as it moved towards the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, later crossed the Western Australian coast, and caused disruption to shipping operations at Christmas Island.
Main_Event_Annotation: The text states that the system 'became a tropical cyclone', which aligns with the Tropical Storm/Cyclone category.
Hazards_Annotation: The cyclone reached peak intensity with winds of 95 km/h, indicating wind as the primary hazard associated with a Tropical Storm/Cyclone.

Time_Annotation: Errol first became a tropical low on 11 January. After developing, the system moved in a general southwest to west direction, becoming a tropical cyclone at 00:00 UTC on the 13th. Errol slowly intensified over the coming days, reaching its peak intensity on 15 January with winds of 100 km/h (60 mph) and an estimated central pressure of 980 hPa as it recurved towards the southeast. After peaking, the storm weakened and Errol merged with Cyclone Bruno on the 18 January.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: The storm caused flood damage in Western Australia.
Main_Event_Annotation: After developing, the system moved in a general southwest to west direction, becoming a tropical cyclone at 00:00 UTC on the 13th.
Hazards_Annotation: Errol reached its peak intensity with winds of 100 km/h (60 mph) and the storm caused flood damage in Western Australia.

Hazards_Annotation: The measures described—including undergrounding power lines in high-fire risk areas, installation of wildfire detection cameras, and public safety power shutoffs during extreme fire weather conditions—underscore Wildfire as the associated hazard.

Specific_Instance_Per_Administrative_Are.Annotation: In August, a typhoon struck near Wenzhou, China, killing 50,000 people.[5]
In September, a typhoon killed 1,000 people and left US$20 million in damage when it struck Japan and sank the SS Kiche Maru.[10]
In November, typhoon struck Tacloban, Philippines, killing 15,000 people.
Also, on November 26, a typhoon struck Palau, killing two people.[3]

Total_Summary_Buildings_Damaged.Total_Buildings_Damaged_Annotation: The text describes damage to numerous individual structures but does not provide an overall total number of damaged buildings.

Specific_Instance_Per_Administrative_Are.Annotation: CNN Center was severely damaged, including shattered windows; later reports mentioned damage to its glass atrium roof (flooding part of the food court) and blown-out windows in the CNN.com newsroom and videotape library.
The Georgia World Congress Center sustained serious damage and later experienced flooding while hosting a JROTC event and the Hinman Dental Meeting.

The Omni Hotel was damaged—especially the skywalk between its two hotel towers over Andrew Young International Boulevard—with the complex losing 476 windows and necessitating the closure of its south tower.
The facades of the Georgia Dome and a Philips Arena parking garage were damaged while hosting basketball games.
Two of the giant columns in Centennial Olympic Park were knocked down.

The Ritz Carlton, Westin Peachtree Plaza, Georgia-Pacific Building, SunTrust Plaza (where more than 60 people were relocated out of their offices), Equitable Building (noting 300 windows blown out), Georgia State University, and the Tabernacle had windows blown out.
Due to falling windows from the Westin, several city blocks and MARTA's Peachtree Center station were closed to pedestrians.
The historic Rialto Theatre at GSU sustained roof damage that resulted in water damage inside.
Grady Hospital reported some damage to windows and experienced a power outage.
The King Memorial MARTA station was damaged and trains were rerouted with buses sent to the adjacent station.
A brick loft building in the Cabbagetown area lost part of its roof and a portion of its top (fifth) floor.
Another building at The Stacks on Boulevard was damaged; search and rescue personnel were initially unable to enter, though everyone was later accounted for.
At Philips Arena, despite the damage to the exterior, attendees noticed little disruption during the game.
Over 20 homes were completely destroyed.

Specific_Instance_Per_Administrative_Are.Annotation: Twenty-seven people were treated for injuries at Philips Arena.

Event_Name: Worst April Heatwave in Asian History
Time_Annotation: The sentence 'During mid-April 2023, heat waves occurred in several countries in South Asia, Indochina, and parts of China.' indicates the start period, and the sentence 'In May, Vietnam recorded its highest ever temperature of 44.1 °C (111.4 °F).' indicates that the event continued into May.
Administrative_Areas_Annotation: Laos is referenced in 'In Luang Prabang, Laos, temperatures reached 42.7 °C (108.9 °F)', Thailand in 'while neighboring Thailand reached a record-tying 44.6 °C (112.3 °F)', India in 'At least 13 people died in Maharashtra state, India', Vietnam in 'In May, Vietnam recorded its highest ever temperature of 44.1 °C (111.4 °F)', and China in '...parts of China.'
